title: 108_s1613
content: The Act is titled the "United States Independent Film and Television Production Incentive Act of 2003" and provides tax incentives for qualified US independent film and television production through a new section called "SEC. 45G. UNITED STATES INDEPENDENT FILM AND TELEVISION PRODUCTION WAGE CREDIT." The United States independent film and television production wage credit is 25% of qualified wages per production, with a limit of $25,000 per employee. Eligible taxpayers must derive most of their income from active production. The United States independent film and television production wage credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified wages per production, capped at $25,000 per employee. Eligible taxpayers must primarily earn income from active production. Qualified wages include payments for services performed in the U.S. by qualified employees, fringe benefits, payments to personal service corporations, and remuneration for services rendered in the U.S. The term 'qualified employee' refers to individuals who render personal services in activities related to qualified US independent film and television productions. Certain individuals are not eligible for this classification. The term 'wages' in this section has the same meaning as in section 51. 'Employee fringe benefit expenses' include employer contributions to retirement plans, health insurance coverage, and life/disability insurance for employees. No other wage credits are allowed if the employer claims a credit under this section. The term 'wages' in this section has the same meaning as in section 51. 'Employee fringe benefit expenses' include employer contributions to retirement plans, health insurance coverage, and life/disability insurance for employees. No other wage credits are allowed if the employer claims a credit under this section. Any amount treated as wages under paragraph (1)(A) shall not be taken into account under this subparagraph. Qualified United States Independent Film and Television Production refers to productions with 75% of total wages as qualified wages, created primarily for public entertainment or educational purposes, and with a total production cost between $200,000 and $7,500,000. The production described in this paragraph includes motion pictures, television series, mini-series, movies of the week, and pilot productions, with a total production cost between $200,000 and $7,500,000. The term 'public entertainment' includes motion pictures, video tapes, and television programs intended for broadcast or cable distribution, excluding productions requiring records under section 2257 of title 18, United States Code. The text chunk discusses the criteria for films to be rated for violent or adult content, the treatment of controlled groups for tax credit purposes, and the application of certain rules. It also mentions the option for employers to elect not to apply the credit. The text chunk discusses the election option for taxpayers to not apply the credit for a taxable year and the amendment to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the United States independent film and television production wage credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to disallow carryback of the section 45g credit before January 1, 2004. Additionally, double benefits are denied for certain expenses related to credits, and conforming amendments are made to various sections.
